content.div:
She may not have the voice nor bear a passing resemblance to Whitney Houston, but there is no doubt that Rihanna has the life experience to match that of the late singer, whose story is rumoured to be turned into a movie starring the "S&M" singer.

According to The Daily Mail, Riri is the current favourite to star in an upcoming Houston biopic, with Grammy tribute singer Jennifer Hudson, Vivica A. Fox and Jordin Sparks also up for the part.

As many pointed out when the both Houston and Rihanna were featured at this year's Grammys, the two have more than just charts in common; both suffered abuse at the hands of their pop star companions (Bobby Brown and Chris Brown, respectively).

According to a People source, "Whitney knew about the project and was excited to see where it would lead" and hoped the film would be "as successful as Tina Turner movie What's Love Got To Do With It," which famously exposed the singer's abuse at the hands of former husband Ike Turner.

For her part, Rihanna has previously gone on the record to say she wasn't interested in playing a singer in films, telling OK! Magazine that she wanted to play "characters."

"My whole life is playing Rihanna, [so] being a singer [in a film] won't be a stretch for me."

Her first feature film role is in May's Battleship, alongside Taylor Kitsch.

However, if the "Rude Boy" singer does decide to play Houston, it wouldn't be the first time she was hypocritical in the press.

jond@dose.ca

entry.title: 2012 Grammy Awards - Best and Worst Moments

link.Abstract: It's music's biggest -- and longest -- night. Adele, Foo Fighters, Whitney Houston and more made for some of the most memorable moments of the 54th Annual Grammy Awards.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars. Typically, though, they're in the audience -- collecting more trophies than their Versace-clad arms can carry. That was certainly true of Sunday's edition -- with the likes of Adele, Kanye West and the Foo Fighters being lauded. But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evening, but that didn't stop the 54th Annual Grammy Awards from being the marathon, three and a half hour party it always is. Check out some of the highlights.
--Leah Collins/Dose.ca
link.title: As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars.
